Award.AwardTitle: The Physics and Applications of High Brightness Beams
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for students to participate in one of the primary workshops on accelerator science endorsed by the International Committee for Future Accelerators, "The Physics and Applications of High Brightness Beams" to be held in Havana, Cuba, on March 28 - April 1, 2016. The workshop will maintain and further refine the previous central thrusts of the meeting: to examine the state-of-the-art in high brightness beam physics and technology as it is applied in advanced accelerators and light sources. The choice of the location of the workshop indicates a continuing commitment to outreach to include a wider range of participants, including scientists from developing countries. The location of the workshop is also expected to help launch a new initiative that seeks to introduce the beginnings of light source infrastructure in the Caribbean basin. The workshop has obtained the endorsement of UNESCO and a broad spectrum of participants from the United States, Cuba, Latin America, Asia, and Europe is expected.

The award will be used to provide partial travel support for US students to attend the workshop. The recipients of the travel support will be making presentations at the workshop. Attendance of 18 US students will be facilitated by the funds provided by this award. The workshop will be an excellent opportunity for young scientists to interact with more experienced researchers and their colleagues in the broader international scientific community. This award is co-sponsored by the NSF's Physics Division and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant helped give vital support to the latest incarnation of a series of workshops endorsed by International Committee on Future Accelerators (ICFA) on the Physics and Applications of High Brightness Beams, which has been held at the Hotel Nacional in Havana, Cuba between March 28 and April 1, 2016. In total, 135 participants coming from 14 different countries attended this historic conference. In recognition of its pioneering role in the significant blossoming of relations between Cuba and the larger scientific community, this workshop also received the endorsement of UNESCO. The workshop, in addition to the US NSF, had a number of international sponsors, including UCLA, INFN, and DESY. The workshop web site, which contains detailed information on the workshop’s scientific agenda, is found at https://conferences.pa.ucla.edu/hbb/.

The location of the workshop indicates a continuing commitment to outreach in our field, to include a wider range of participants, most notably scientists from developing countries. To recognize significant emerging trends in novel high brightness ion sources as well as historic interest in particle and nuclear physics in Cuba, the host nation, this workshop also embraced next-generation high brightness ion sources. The subjects surrounding advanced ion beams included sources based on laser plasma interaction, and the new experimental possibilities and applications — particularly in biomedical applications — opened by this exciting field.

This version of the workshop maintained and further refined the previous central thrusts of the meeting, to examine the state-of-the-art in high brightness beam physics and technology as it is applied in advanced accelerators and light sources. In recent workshops, a more ambitious agenda has emerged, the effective joining advanced acceleration techniques and novel light sources into one application: the “5th generation light source”. This synthesis entails creating extremely compact, high brilliance short wavelength radiations sources enabled by beams accelerated in ultra-high gradient accelerators based on plasmas, lasers and intense beams. The advanced accelerators operate at unprecedented high fields, to above the GV/m level, and produce beams having extremely challenging length and time scales. Both the beam physics and revolutionary applications implied by the 5th generation light source require rethinking of the principles and experimental methods employed. New initiatives are now underway dedicated to the rapid adoption this exciting new scenario, aiming to yield a new type of compact light source within a decade. This focused effort will apply impetus to the development and maturation of such new methods, and as such may be viewed as an essential stepping-stone on the path to higher energy applications such as the linear collider. The concept of the 5th generation light source was spotlighted in the conference in a session dedicated to a possible pan-Caribbean initiative to develop a next generation light source. This discussion centered on advanced concepts such as Compton scattering sources that would enable frontier science in emerging nations.

The rich discussions of the meeting are captured well in the presentations that are available on the workshop web site. The results of the workshop are also formally recorded in the proceedings papers published in a special issue of Nuclear Instruments and Methods A. Beyond this tangible evidence of the workshop’s impact, the meeting served to open up scientific and cultural relations between Cuba and the rest of the world, particularly in the US. Participants will remember the unmatched hospitality of the Cuban hosts. They shared with visitors, many of whom overcame significant administrative hurdles to participate, a wide selection of their cultural heritage. Through art and music - from the Cuban National Opera to the Buena Vista Social Club -  as well as science, all who came to Cuba for this historic workshop are left with a profound appreciation for the Cuban peoples’ history, as well as their future prospects.
